v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/admin-settin.title: Authentication, Permissions and Global Configuration
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/admin-settin.description: After installation, the system administrator should configure Rancher to configure authentication, authorization, security, default settings, security policies, drivers and global DNS entries.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.title: Configuring Active Directory (AD)
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.description: If your organization uses Microsoft Active Directory as central user repository, you can configure Rancher to communicate with an Active Directory server to authenticate users. This allows Rancher admins to control access to clusters and projects based on users and groups managed externally in the Active Directory, while allowing end-users to authenticate with their AD credentials when logging in to the Rancher UI.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.title: Authentication
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.description: One of the key features that Rancher adds to Kubernetes is centralized user authentication. This feature allows your users to use one set of credentials to authenticate with any of your Kubernetes clusters.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.title: Configuring GitHub
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.description: In environments using GitHub, you can configure Rancher to allow sign on using GitHub credentials.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.title: Configuring Keycloak (SAML)
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.description: Create a Keycloak SAML client and configure Rancher to work with Keycloak. By the end your users will be able to sign into Rancher using their Keycloak logins

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.title: Local Authentication
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.description: Local authentication is the default until you configure an external authentication provider. Local authentication is where Rancher stores the user information, i.e. names and passwords, of who can log in to Rancher. By default, the admin user that logs in to Rancher for the first time is a local user.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.title: Configuring Microsoft Active Directory Federation Service (SAML)
1. Configuring Microsoft AD FS for Rancher
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.description: Before configuring Rancher to support AD FS users, you must add Rancher as a relying party trust in AD FS.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.title: 2. Configuring Rancher for Microsoft AD FS
OpenLDAP Configuration Reference
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.description: This section is intended to be used as a reference when setting up an OpenLDAP authentication provider in Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.title: Group Permissions with Shibboleth and OpenLDAP
Users and Groups
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/authenticati.description: Rancher relies on users and groups to determine who is allowed to log in to Rancher and which resources they can access. When you configure an external authentication provider, users from that provider will be able to log in to your Rancher server. When a user logs in, the authentication provider will supply your Rancher server with a list of groups to which the user belongs.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/config-priva.title: Configuring a Global Default Private Registry
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/config-priva.description: You might want to use a private container registry to share your custom base images within your organization. With a private registry, you can keep a private, consistent, and centralized source of truth for the container images that are used in your clusters.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/drivers/driv.title: Provisioning Drivers
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/drivers/driv.description: Drivers in Rancher allow you to manage which providers can be used to deploy hosted Kubernetes clusters or nodes in an infrastructure provider to allow Rancher to deploy and manage Kubernetes.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/drivers/node.title: Node Drivers
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/drivers/node.description: Node drivers are used to provision hosts, which Rancher uses to launch and manage Kubernetes clusters. A node driver is the same as a Docker Machine driver. The availability of which node driver to display when creating node templates is defined based on the node driver's status. Only active node drivers will be displayed as an option for creating node templates. By default, Rancher is packaged with many existing Docker Machine drivers, but you can also create custom node drivers to add to Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/pod-security.title: Pod Security Policies
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/pod-security.description: Pod Security Policies (or PSPs) are objects that control security-sensitive aspects of pod specification (like root privileges).

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/cluster.title: Cluster and Project Roles
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/cluster.description: Cluster and project roles define user authorization inside a cluster or project. You can manage these roles from the Global > Security > Roles page.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/default.title: Custom Roles
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/default.description: Within Rancher, roles determine what actions a user can make within a cluster or project.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/global-.title: Global Permissions
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/global-.description: Permissions are individual access rights that you can assign when selecting a custom permission for a user.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/locked-.title: Locked Roles
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/locked-.description: You can set roles to a status of locked. Locking roles prevent them from being assigned users in the future.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/rbac.title: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rbac/rbac.description: Within Rancher, each person authenticates as a user, which is a login that grants you access to Rancher. As mentioned in Authentication, users can either be local or external.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: Applying Templates
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: You can create a cluster from an RKE template that you created, or from a template that has been shared with you.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: Creating and Revising Templates
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: This section describes how to manage RKE templates and revisions. You an create, share, update, and delete templates from the Global view under Tools > RKE Templates.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: Template Creator Permissions
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: Administrators have the permission to create RKE templates, and only administrators can give that permission to other users.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: Template Enforcement
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: This section describes how template administrators can enforce templates in Rancher, restricting the ability of users to create clusters without a template.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: Example Scenarios
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: These example scenarios describe how an organization could use templates to standardize cluster creation.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: Example YAML
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: Below is an example RKE template configuration file for reference.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: Overriding Template Settings
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: When a user creates an RKE template, each setting in the template has a switch in the Rancher UI that indicates if users can override the setting. This switch marks those settings as Allow User Override.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: RKE Templates and Infrastructure
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: In Rancher, RKE templates are used to provision Kubernetes and define Rancher settings, while node templates are used to provision nodes.

v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.title: Access and Sharing
v2.0-v2.4/en/admin-settings/rke-template.description: If you are an RKE template owner, you can share it with users or groups of users, who can then use the template to create clusters.

v2.0-v2.4/en/api/api-tokens/api-tokens.title: API Tokens
v2.0-v2.4/en/api/api-tokens/api-tokens.description: By default, some cluster-level API tokens are generated with infinite time-to-live (ttl=0). In other words, API tokens with ttl=0 never expire unless you invalidate them. Tokens are not invalidated by changing a password.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backup/backup.title: Backup
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backup/backup.description: This section contains information about how to create backups of your Rancher data and how to restore them in a disaster scenario.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backup/docker-backu.title: Backing up Rancher Installed with Docker
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backup/docker-backu.description: After completing your Docker installation of Rancher, we recommend creating backups of it on a regular basis. Having a recent backup will let you recover quickly from an unexpected disaster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backup/k3s-backups/.title: Backing up Rancher Installed on a K3s Kubernetes Cluster
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backup/k3s-backups/.description: When Rancher is installed on a high-availability Kubernetes cluster, we recommend using an external database to store the cluster data.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backup/rke-backups/.title: Backing up Rancher Installed on an RKE Kubernetes Cluster
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backup/rke-backups/.description: This section describes how to create backups of your high-availability Rancher install.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backups.title: Backups and Disaster Recovery
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/backups.description: This section is devoted to protecting your data in a disaster scenario.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/docker-rest.title: Restoring Backups—Docker Installs
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/docker-rest.description: If you encounter a disaster scenario, you can restore your Rancher Server to your most recent backup.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/k3s-restore.title: Restoring Rancher Installed on a K3s Kubernetes Cluster
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/k3s-restore.description: When Rancher is installed on a high-availability Kubernetes cluster, we recommend using an external database to store the cluster data.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/restore.title: Restore
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/restore.description: If you lose the data on your Rancher Server, you can restore it if you have backups stored in a safe location.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/rke-restore.title: Restoring Backups—Kubernetes installs
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/rke-restore.description: This procedure describes how to use RKE to restore a snapshot of the Rancher Kubernetes cluster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/rke-restore.title: Rolling back to v2.0.0-v2.1.5
v2.0-v2.4/en/backups/restore/rke-restore.description: Rolling back to Rancher v2.0-v2.1 is no longer supported. The instructions for rolling back to these versions are preserved here and are intended to be used only in cases where upgrading to Rancher v2.2+ is not feasible.

v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/best-practic.title: Best Practices Guide
v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/best-practic.description: The purpose of this section is to consolidate best practices for Rancher implementations. This also includes recommendations for related technologies, such as Kubernetes, Docker, containers, and more. The objective is to improve the outcome of a Rancher implementation using the operational experience of Rancher and its customers.

v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/containers/c.title: Tips for Setting Up Containers
v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/containers/c.description: Running well-built containers can greatly impact the overall performance and security of your environment.

v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/deployment-s.title: Rancher Deployment Strategies
v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/deployment-s.description: There are two recommended deployment strategies. Each one has its own pros and cons. Read more about which one would fit best for your use case:

v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/deployment-t.title: Tips for Running Rancher
v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/deployment-t.description: A high-availability Kubernetes installation, defined as an installation of Rancher on a Kubernetes cluster with at least three nodes, should be used in any production installation of Rancher, as well as any installation deemed "important." Multiple Rancher instances running on multiple nodes ensure high availability that cannot be accomplished with a single node environment.

v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/management/m.title: Tips for Scaling, Security and Reliability
v2.0-v2.4/en/best-practices/management/m.description: Rancher allows you to set up numerous combinations of configurations. Some configurations are more appropriate for development and testing, while there are other best practices for production environments for maximum availability and fault tolerance. The following best practices should be followed for production.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cli/cli.title: Using the Rancher Command Line Interface
v2.0-v2.4/en/cli/cli.description: The Rancher CLI is a unified tool that you can use to interact with Rancher. With it, you can operate Rancher using a command line interface rather than the GUI

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/certificate-r.title: Certificate Rotation
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/certificate-r.description: Warning: Rotating Kubernetes certificates may result in your cluster being temporarily unavailable as components are restarted. For production environments, it's recommended to perform this action during a maintenance window.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cleaning-clus.title: Removing Kubernetes Components from Nodes
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cleaning-clus.description: Learn about cluster cleanup when removing nodes from your Rancher-launched Kubernetes cluster. What is removed, how to do it manually

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cloning-clust.title: Cloning Clusters
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cloning-clust.description: If you have a cluster in Rancher that you want to use as a template for creating similar clusters, you can use Rancher CLI to clone the cluster's configuration, edit it, and then use it to quickly launch the cloned cluster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-acces.title: How the Authorized Cluster Endpoint Works
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-acces.description: This section describes how the kubectl CLI, the kubeconfig file, and the authorized cluster endpoint work together to allow you to access a downstream Kubernetes cluster directly, without authenticating through the Rancher server. It is intended to provide background information and context to the instructions for how to set up kubectl to directly access a cluster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-acces.title: Cluster Access
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-acces.description: This section is about what tools can be used to access clusters managed by Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-acces.title: Adding Users to Clusters
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-acces.description: If you want to provide a user with access and permissions to all projects, nodes, and resources within a cluster, assign the user a cluster membership.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-acces.title: Access a Cluster with Kubectl and kubeconfig
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-acces.description: Learn how you can access and manage your Kubernetes clusters using kubectl with kubectl Shell or with kubectl CLI and kubeconfig file. A kubeconfig file is used to configure access to Kubernetes. When you create a cluster with Rancher, it automatically creates a kubeconfig for your cluster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-admin.title: Cluster Administration
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-admin.description: After you provision a cluster in Rancher, you can begin using powerful Kubernetes features to deploy and scale your containerized applications in development, testing, or production environments.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-autos.title: Cluster Autoscaler with AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-autos.description: This guide will show you how to install and use Kubernetes cluster-autoscaler on Rancher custom clusters using AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-autos.title: Cluster Autoscaler
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/cluster-autos.description: In this section, you'll learn how to install and use the Kubernetes cluster-autoscaler on Rancher custom clusters using AWS EC2 Auto Scaling Groups.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/editing-clust.title: Cluster Configuration
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/editing-clust.description: After you provision a Kubernetes cluster using Rancher, you can still edit options and settings for the cluster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/nodes/nodes.title: Nodes and Node Pools
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/nodes/nodes.description: After you launch a Kubernetes cluster in Rancher, you can manage individual nodes from the cluster's Node tab. Depending on the option used to provision the cluster, there are different node options available.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/pod-security-.title: Adding a Pod Security Policy
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/pod-security-.description: Prerequisite: The options below are available only for clusters that are launched using RKE.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/projects-and-.title: Projects and Kubernetes Namespaces with Rancher
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/projects-and-.description: Rancher Projects ease the administrative burden of your cluster and support multi-tenancy. Learn to create projects and divide projects into Kubernetes namespaces

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cis-sca.title: Skipped and Not Applicable Tests
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cis-sca.description: This section lists the tests that are skipped in the permissive test profile for RKE.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Cluster Alerts
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: To keep your clusters and applications healthy and driving your organizational productivity forward, you need to stay informed of events occurring in your clusters and projects, both planned and unplanned. When an event occurs, your alert is triggered, and you are sent a notification. You can then, if necessary, follow up with corrective actions.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Default Alerts for Cluster Monitoring
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: When you create a cluster, some alert rules are predefined. These alerts notify you about signs that the cluster could be unhealthy. You can receive these alerts if you configure a notifier for them.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Cluster Logging
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: Rancher integrates with popular logging services. Learn the requirements and benefits of integrating with logging services, and enable logging on your cluster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Elasticsearch
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: If your organization uses Elasticsearch, either on premise or in the cloud, you can configure Rancher to send it Kubernetes logs. Afterwards, you can log into your Elasticsearch deployment to view logs.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Fluentd
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: If your organization uses Fluentd, you can configure Rancher to send it Kubernetes logs.  Afterwards, you can log into your Fluentd server to view logs.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Kafka
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: If your organization uses Kafka, you can configure Rancher to send it Kubernetes logs.  Afterwards, you can log into your Kafka server to view logs.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Splunk
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: If your organization uses Splunk, you can configure Rancher to send it Kubernetes logs. Afterwards, you can log into your Splunk server to view logs.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Syslog
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: If your organization uses Syslog, you can configure Rancher to send it Kubernetes logs. Afterwards, you can log into your Syslog server to view logs.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Integrating Rancher and Prometheus for Cluster Monitoring
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: Prometheus lets you view metrics from your different Rancher and Kubernetes objects. Learn about the scope of monitoring and how to enable cluster monitoring

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Prometheus Custom Metrics Adapter
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: After you've enabled cluster level monitoring, You can view the metrics data from Rancher. You can also deploy the Prometheus custom metrics adapter then you can use the HPA with metrics stored in cluster monitoring.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.title: Prometheus Expressions
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/cluster.description: The PromQL expressions in this doc can be used to configure alerts.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/d.title: Disabling Istio
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/d.description: This section describes how to disable Istio in a cluster, namespace, or workload.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/r.title: Role-based Access Control
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/r.description: This section describes the permissions required to access Istio features and how to configure access to the Kiali and Jaeger visualizations.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: 4. Add Deployments and Services with the Istio Sidecar
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: Prerequisite: To enable Istio for a workload, the cluster and namespace must have Istio enabled.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: 1. Enable Istio in the Cluster
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: This cluster uses the default Nginx controller to allow traffic into the cluster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: Enable Istio with Pod Security Policies
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: Note: The following guide is only for RKE provisioned clusters.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: 2. Enable Istio in a Namespace
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: You will need to manually enable Istio in each namespace that you want to be tracked or controlled by Istio. When Istio is enabled in a namespace, the Envoy sidecar proxy will be automatically injected into all new workloads that are deployed in the namespace.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: 5. Set up the Istio Gateway
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: The gateway to each cluster can have its own port or load balancer, which is unrelated to a service mesh. By default, each Rancher-provisioned cluster has one NGINX ingress controller allowing traffic into the cluster.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: 3. Select the Nodes Where Istio Components Will be Deployed
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: Prerequisite: Your cluster needs a worker node that can designated for Istio. The worker node should meet the resource requirements.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: 6. Set up Istio's Components for Traffic Management
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: A central advantage of traffic management in Istio is that it allows dynamic request routing. Some common applications for dynamic request routing include canary deployments and blue/green deployments. The two key resources in Istio traffic management are virtual services and destination rules.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: Setup Guide
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: This section describes how to enable Istio and start using it in your projects.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.title: 7. Generate and View Traffic
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/istio/s.description: This section describes how to view the traffic that is being managed by Istio.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/notifie.title: Notifiers
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/notifie.description: Notifiers are services that inform you of alert events. You can configure notifiers to send alert notifications to staff best suited to take corrective action.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/tools.title: Tools for Logging, Monitoring, and More
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/tools/tools.description: Rancher contains a variety of tools that aren't included in Kubernetes to assist in your DevOps operations. Rancher can integrate with external services to help your clusters run more efficiently. Tools are divided into following categories:

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/upgrading-kub.title: Upgrading and Rolling Back Kubernetes
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/upgrading-kub.description: Following an upgrade to the latest version of Rancher, downstream Kubernetes clusters can be upgraded to use the latest supported version of Kubernetes.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: Setting up Existing Storage
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: This section describes how to set up existing persistent storage for workloads in Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: Creating Persistent Storage in Amazon's EBS
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: This section describes how to set up Amazon's Elastic Block Store in EC2.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: Provisioning Storage Examples
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: Rancher supports persistent storage with a variety of volume plugins. However, before you use any of these plugins to bind persistent storage to your workloads, you have to configure the storage itself, whether its a cloud-based solution from a service-provider or an on-prem solution that you manage yourself.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: NFS Storage
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: Before you can use the NFS storage volume plug-in with Rancher deployments, you need to provision an NFS server.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: vSphere Storage
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: To provide stateful workloads with vSphere storage, we recommend creating a vSphereVolume StorageClass. This practice dynamically provisions vSphere storage when workloads request volumes through a persistent volume claim.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: GlusterFS Volumes
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: This section only applies to RKE clusters.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: How Persistent Storage Works
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: A persistent volume (PV) is a piece of storage in the Kubernetes cluster, while a persistent volume claim (PVC) is a request for storage.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: iSCSI Volumes
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: In Rancher Launched Kubernetes clusters that store data on iSCSI volumes, you may experience an issue where kubelets fail to automatically connect with iSCSI volumes. This failure is likely due to an incompatibility issue involving the iSCSI initiator tool. You can resolve this issue by installing the iSCSI initiator tool on each of your cluster nodes.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: Dynamically Provisioning New Storage in Rancher
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: This section describes how to provision new persistent storage for workloads in Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.title: Kubernetes Persistent Storage: Volumes and Storage Classes
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-admin/volumes-and-s.description: Learn about the two ways with which you can create persistent storage in Kubernetes: persistent volumes and storage classes

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted.title: Creating an AKS Cluster

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted.title: Creating an EKS Cluster
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted.description: Amazon EKS provides a managed control plane for your Kubernetes cluster. Amazon EKS runs the Kubernetes control plane instances across multiple Availability Zones to ensure high availability. Rancher provides an intuitive user interface for managing and deploying the Kubernetes clusters you run in Amazon EKS. With this guide, you will use Rancher to quickly and easily launch an Amazon EKS Kubernetes cluster in your AWS account. For more information on Amazon EKS, see this documentation.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted.title: Setting up Clusters from Hosted Kubernetes Providers
v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-provisioning/hosted.description: In this scenario, Rancher does not provision Kubernetes because it is installed by providers such as Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE), Amazon Elastic Container Service for Kubernetes, or Azure Kubernetes Service.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-provisioning/node-r.description: This page describes the requirements for the Rancher managed Kubernetes clusters where your apps and services will be installed. These downstream clusters should be separate from the three-node cluster running Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/cluster-provisioning/produc.description: There are three roles that can be assigned to nodes: etcd, controlplane and worker.

v2.0-v2.4/en/faq/kubectl/kubectl.description: kubectl is a CLI utility for running commands against Kubernetes clusters. It's required for many maintenance and administrative tasks in Rancher 2.x.

v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/adding-catalogs.description: Custom catalogs can be added into Rancher at a global scope, cluster scope, or project scope.

v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/built-in/built-.title: Enabling and Disabling Built-in Global Catalogs
v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/built-in/built-.description: There are default global catalogs packaged as part of Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/catalog-config/.title: Custom Catalog Configuration Reference
v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/catalog-config/.description: Any user can create custom catalogs to add into Rancher. Besides the content of the catalog, users must ensure their catalogs are able to be added into Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/creating-apps/c.title: Creating Catalog Apps
v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/creating-apps/c.description: Rancher's catalog service requires any custom catalogs to be structured in a specific format for the catalog service to be able to leverage it in Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/helm-charts.title: Helm Charts in Rancher
v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/helm-charts.description: Rancher enables the use of catalogs to repeatedly deploy applications easily. Catalogs are GitHub or Helm Chart repositories filled with deployment-ready apps.

v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/launching-apps/.title: Launching Catalog Apps
v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/launching-apps/.description: Within a project, when you want to deploy applications from catalogs, the applications available in your project will be based on the scope of the catalogs.

v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/managing-apps/m.title: Managing Catalog Apps
v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/managing-apps/m.description: After deploying an application, one of the benefits of using an application versus individual workloads/resources is the ease of being able to manage many workloads/resources applications. Apps can be cloned, upgraded or rolled back.

v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/tutorial/tutori.title: Tutorial: Example Custom Chart Creation
v2.0-v2.4/en/helm-charts/tutorial/tutori.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to create a Helm chart and deploy it to a  repository. The repository can then be used as a source for a custom catalog in Rancher.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/install-ranche.description: Helm 3 has been released.  If you are using Helm 2, we recommend migrating to Helm 3 because it is simpler to use and more secure than Helm 2.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/install-ranche.description: Important: RKE add-on install is only supported up to Rancher v2.0.8

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.description: This section is about using the Helm CLI to install the Rancher server in an air gapped environment. An air gapped environment could be where Rancher server will be installed offline, behind a firewall, or behind a proxy.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.title: 4. Install Rancher
v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.description: This section is about how to deploy Rancher for your air gapped environment. An air gapped environment could be where Rancher server will be installed offline, behind a firewall, or behind a proxy. There are tabs for either a high availability (recommended) or a Docker installation.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.title: 3. Install Kubernetes (Skip for Docker Installs)
v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.description: Skip this section if you are installing Rancher on a single node with Docker.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.title: 2. Collect and Publish Images to your Private Registry
v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.description: This section describes how to set up your private registry so that when you install Rancher, Rancher will pull all the required images from this registry.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.title: 1. Set up Infrastructure and Private Registry
v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.description: In this section, you will provision the underlying infrastructure for your Rancher management server in an air gapped environment. You will also set up the private Docker registry that must be available to your Rancher node(s).

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.title: Installing Rancher behind an HTTP Proxy
v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.description: In a lot of enterprise environments, servers or VMs running on premise do not have direct Internet access, but must connect to external services through a HTTP(S) proxy for security reasons. This tutorial shows step by step how to set up a highly available Rancher installation in such an environment.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.title: 3. Install Rancher
v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.description: Now that you have a running RKE cluster, you can install Rancher in it. For security reasons all traffic to Rancher must be encrypted with TLS. For this tutorial you are going to automatically issue a self-signed certificate through cert-manager. In a real-world use-case you will likely use Let's Encrypt or provide your own certificate.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/other-installa.title: 2. Install Kubernetes

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/resources/adva.description: You can enable the API audit log to record the sequence of system events initiated by individual users. You can know what happened, when it happened, who initiated it, and what cluster it affected. When you enable this feature, all requests to the Rancher API and all responses from it are written to a log.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/resources/adva.title: Tuning etcd for Large Installations
v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/resources/adva.description: When running larger Rancher installations with 15 or more clusters it is recommended to increase the default keyspace for etcd from the default 2GB. The maximum setting is 8GB and the host should have enough RAM to keep the entire dataset in memory. When increasing this value you should also increase the size of the host. The keyspace size can also be adjusted in smaller installations if you anticipate a high rate of change of pods during the garbage collection interval.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/resources/adva.description: We recommend disabling firewalld. For Kubernetes 1.19.x and higher, firewalld must be turned off.

v2.0-v2.4/en/installation/resources/feat.description: Rancher includes some features that are experimental and disabled by default. You might want to enable these features, for example, if you decide that the benefits of using an unsupported storage type outweighs the risk of using an untested feature. Feature flags were introduced to allow you to try these features that are not enabled by default.

v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/ad.description: A sidecar is a container that extends or enhances the main container in a pod. The main container and the sidecar share a pod, and therefore share the same network space and storage. You can add sidecars to existing workloads by using the Add a Sidecar option.

v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/de.title: Deploying Workloads
v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/de.description: Read this step by step guide for deploying workloads. Deploy a workload to run an application in one or more containers.

v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/ro.title: Rolling Back Workloads
v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/ro.description: Sometimes there is a need to rollback to the previous version of the application, either for debugging purposes or because an upgrade did not go as planned.

v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/up.title: Upgrading Workloads
v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/up.description: When a new version of an application image is released on Docker Hub, you can upgrade any workloads running a previous version of the application to the new one.

v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/wo.title: Kubernetes Workloads and Pods
v2.0-v2.4/en/k8s-in-rancher/workloads/wo.description: Learn about the two constructs with which you can build any complex containerized application in Kubernetes: Kubernetes workloads and pods

v2.0-v2.4/en/overview/architecture-recom.title: Architecture Recommendations
v2.0-v2.4/en/overview/architecture-recom.description: Kubernetes cluster. If you are installing Rancher on a single node, the main architecture recommendation that applies to your installation is that the cluster running Rancher should be separate from downstream clusters.

v2.0-v2.4/en/overview/architecture/archi.title: Architecture
v2.0-v2.4/en/overview/architecture/archi.description: This section focuses on the Rancher server, its components, and how Rancher communicates with downstream Kubernetes clusters.

v2.0-v2.4/en/overview/concepts/concepts.title: Kubernetes Concepts
v2.0-v2.4/en/overview/concepts/concepts.description: This page explains concepts related to Kubernetes that are important for understanding how Rancher works. The descriptions below provide a simplified interview of Kubernetes components. For more details, refer to the official documentation on Kubernetes components.

v2.0-v2.4/en/overview/overview.title: Overview
v2.0-v2.4/en/overview/overview.description: Rancher is a container management platform built for organizations that deploy containers in production. Rancher makes it easy to run Kubernetes everywhere, meet IT requirements, and empower DevOps teams.

v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/concepts/concepts.title: Concepts
v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/concepts/concepts.description: The purpose of this page is to explain common concepts and terminology related to pipelines.

v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/config/config.title: Pipeline Configuration Reference
v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/config/config.description: In this section, you'll learn how to configure pipelines.

v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/docs-for-v2.0.x/d.title: v2.0.x Pipeline Documentation
v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/docs-for-v2.0.x/d.description: Note: This section describes the pipeline feature as implemented in Rancher v2.0.x. If you are using Rancher v2.1 or later, where pipelines have been significantly improved, please refer to the new documentation for v2.1 or later.

v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/example-repos/exa.title: Example Repositories
v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/example-repos/exa.description: Rancher ships with several example repositories that you can use to familiarize yourself with pipelines. We recommend configuring and testing the example repository that most resembles your environment before using pipelines with your own repositories in a production environment. Use this example repository as a sandbox for repo configuration, build demonstration, etc. Rancher includes example repositories for:

v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/example/example.title: Example YAML File
v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/example/example.description: Pipelines can be configured either through the UI or using a yaml file in the repository, i.e. .rancher-pipeline.yml or .rancher-pipeline.yaml.

v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/pipelines.title: Pipelines
v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/pipelines.description: Rancher's pipeline provides a simple CI/CD experience. Use it to automatically checkout code, run builds or scripts, publish Docker images or catalog applications, and deploy the updated software to users.

v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/storage/storage.title: Configuring Persistent Data for Pipeline Components
v2.0-v2.4/en/pipelines/storage/storage.description: The pipelines' internal Docker registry and the Minio workloads use ephemeral volumes by default. This default storage works out-of-the-box and makes testing easy, but you lose the build images and build logs if the node running the Docker Registry or Minio fails. In most cases this is fine. If you want build images and logs to survive node failures, you can configure the Docker Registry and Minio to use persistent volumes.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/namespaces/na.title: Namespaces
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/namespaces/na.description: Within Rancher, you can further divide projects into different namespaces, which are virtual clusters within a project backed by a physical cluster. Should you require another level of organization beyond projects and the default namespace, you can use multiple namespaces to isolate applications and resources.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/pipelines/pip.title: Rancher's CI/CD Pipelines
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/pipelines/pip.description: Use Rancher’s CI/CD pipeline to automatically checkout code, run builds or scripts, publish Docker images, and deploy software to users

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/pod-security-.title: Pod Security Policies
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/pod-security-.description: These cluster options are only available for clusters in which Rancher has launched Kubernetes.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/project-admin.title: Project Administration
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/project-admin.description: Projects are objects introduced in Rancher that help organize namespaces in your Kubernetes cluster. You can use projects to create multi-tenant clusters, which allows a group of users to share the same underlying resources without interacting with each other's applications.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/project-membe.title: Adding Users to Projects
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/project-membe.description: If you want to provide a user with access and permissions to specific projects and resources within a cluster, assign the user a project membership.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/resource-quot.title: Overriding the Default Limit for a Namespace
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/resource-quot.description: Although the Namespace Default Limit propagates from the project to each namespace when created, in some cases, you may need to increase (or decrease) the quotas for a specific namespace. In this situation, you can override the default limits by editing the namespace.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/resource-quot.title: Resource Quota Type Reference
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/resource-quot.description: When you create a resource quota, you are configuring the pool of resources available to the project. You can set the following resource limits for the following resource types.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/resource-quot.title: How Resource Quotas Work in Rancher Projects
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/resource-quot.description: Resource quotas in Rancher include the same functionality as the native version of Kubernetes. However, in Rancher, resource quotas have been extended so that you can apply them to projects.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/tools/project.title: Project Alerts
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/tools/project.description: To keep your clusters and applications healthy and driving your organizational productivity forward, you need to stay informed of events occurring in your clusters and projects, both planned and unplanned. When an event occurs, your alert is triggered, and you are sent a notification. You can then, if necessary, follow up with corrective actions.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/tools/project.title: Project Logging
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/tools/project.description: Rancher can integrate with a variety of popular logging services and tools that exist outside of your Kubernetes clusters.

v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/tools/tools.title: Tools for Logging, Monitoring, and More
v2.0-v2.4/en/project-admin/tools/tools.description: Rancher contains a variety of tools that aren't included in Kubernetes to assist in your DevOps operations. Rancher can integrate with external services to help your clusters run more efficiently. Tools are divided into following categories:

v2.0-v2.4/en/security/cve/cve.description: Rancher is committed to informing the community of security issues in our products. Rancher will publish CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) for issues we have resolved.

v2.0-v2.4/en/user-settings/node-template.title: Managing Node Templates
v2.0-v2.4/en/user-settings/node-template.description: When you provision a cluster hosted by an infrastructure provider, node templates are used to provision the cluster nodes. These templates use Docker Machine configuration options to define an operating system image and settings/parameters for the node. You can create node templates in two contexts:

v2.0-v2.4/en/user-settings/preferences/p.title: User Preferences
v2.0-v2.4/en/user-settings/preferences/p.description: Each user can choose preferences to personalize their Rancher experience. To change preference settings, open the User Settings menu and then select Preferences.

v2.0-v2.4/en/user-settings/user-settings.title: User Settings
v2.0-v2.4/en/user-settings/user-settings.description: Within Rancher, each user has a number of settings associated with their login: personal preferences, API keys, etc. You can configure these settings by choosing from the User Settings menu. You can open this menu by clicking your avatar, located within the main menu.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/discover-ser.title: 6. Service Discovery
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/discover-ser.description: Service discovery is one of the core functionalities of any container-based environment. Once you have packaged and launched your application, the next step is making it discoverable to other containers in your environment or the external world. This document will describe how to use the service discovery support provided by Rancher v2.x so that you can find them by name.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/expose-servi.title: 3. Expose Your Services
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/expose-servi.description: In testing environments, you usually need to route external traffic to your cluster containers by using an unadvertised IP and port number, providing users access to their apps. You can accomplish this goal using port mapping, which exposes a workload (i.e., service) publicly over a specific port, provided you know your node IP address(es). You can either map a port using HostPorts (which exposes a service on a specified port on a single node) or NodePorts (which exposes a service on all nodes on a single port).

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/get-started/.title: 1. Get Started
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/get-started/.description: Get started with your migration to Rancher v2.x by installing Rancher and configuring your new Rancher environment.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/kub-intro/ku.title: Kubernetes Introduction
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/kub-intro/ku.description: Rancher v2.x is built on the Kubernetes container orchestrator. This shift in underlying technology for v2.x is a large departure from v1.6, which supported several popular container orchestrators. Since Rancher is now based entirely on Kubernetes, it's helpful to learn the Kubernetes basics.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/load-balanci.title: 7. Load Balancing
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/load-balanci.description: If your applications are public-facing and consume significant traffic, you should place a load balancer in front of your cluster so that users can always access their apps without service interruption. Typically, you can fulfill a high volume of service requests by horizontally scaling your deployment, which spins up additional application containers as traffic ramps up. However, this technique requires routing that distributes traffic across your nodes efficiently. In cases where you need to accommodate public traffic that scales up and down, you'll need a load balancer.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/monitor-apps.title: 4. Configure Health Checks
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/monitor-apps.description: Rancher v1.6 provided TCP and HTTP health checks on your nodes and services using its own health check microservice. These health checks monitored your containers to confirm they're operating as intended. If a container failed a health check, Rancher would destroy the unhealthy container and then replicates a healthy one to replace it.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/run-migratio.title: Migration Tools CLI Reference
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/run-migratio.description: The migration-tools CLI includes multiple commands and options to assist your migration from Rancher v1.6 to Rancher v2.x.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/run-migratio.title: 2. Migrate Your Services
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/run-migratio.description: Although your services from v1.6 won't work in Rancher v2.x by default, that doesn't mean you have to start again from square one, manually rebuilding your applications in v2.x. To help with migration from v1.6 to v2.x, Rancher has developed a migration tool. The migration-tools CLI is a utility that helps you recreate your applications in Rancher v2.x. This tool exports your Rancher v1.6 services as Compose files and converts them to a Kubernetes manifest that Rancher v2.x can consume.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/schedule-wor.title: 5. Schedule Your Services
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/schedule-wor.description: In v1.6, objects called services were used to schedule containers to your cluster hosts. Services included the Docker image for an application, along with configuration settings for a desired state.

v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/v1.6-migrati.title: Migrating from v1.6 to v2.x
v2.0-v2.4/en/v1.6-migration/v1.6-migrati.description: Rancher v2.x has been rearchitected and rewritten with the goal of providing a complete management solution for Kubernetes and Docker.  Due to these extensive changes, there is no direct upgrade path from v1.6 to v2.x, but rather a migration of your v1.6 services into v2.x as Kubernetes workloads.  In v1.6, the most common orchestration used was Rancher's own engine called Cattle. The following guide explains and educates our Cattle users on running workloads in a Kubernetes environment.
